text:
I've been wanting to try Ethiopian food for the longest time - we found a groupon deal - came with Meat Combo
Food taste a lot like Indian food, gravy, bit spicy and serve with traditional bread
The pancake is kinda sour to eat by itself but pair perfectly with the heavier spiced dishes 

Give it a try !

Never had Ethiopian food.... Much like Indian food.... My husband and I got the vegetable assortment and meat assortment.... They refilled the vegetables as much as we wanted in small quantities.... The teff was the Ethiopian bread.. It was kinda like a crepe but not!!! It was spongy weird consistency with a very sour taste.... I would much prefer naan to eat with that kind of food.... It was very difficult to understand the waitress, but I was there for the experience and I got it!!! The location and ambiance was little to be desired.... I would eat Ethiopian food again as long as I have a groupon... Food was good, just the atmosphere would be the reason I might not go back.... But, maybe I would.... Owners and employees were sweet!
Planning on dinning the famous veggie combo, for the month of lent. Great service, generous portion and reasonable price.

Not impressed.

So many REALLY good Ethiopian restaurants in Las Vegas.

Menu ... well, they only brought half of it. When asked for some traditional dishes, I was looked at very strange. Then she brought the other menu with what I was looking for. Prices did not make much sense and portion compared to the price was not good.  Also, asked for NO SPICE - it was loaded with jalapenos. Hmmmmm.

I could get over a lot of this, but I was using a Groupon and they tried mis-charging me.

Then, the biggest problem ... there is no way the dining area or bathroom would pass any health inspection ... very dirty! Like it was never cleaned - ever.

This is in the location of the original Viva Mercado.

Oh yeah, they wanted to charge me a $1 service charge for using a credit card.  Really?

If you have never tried Ethiopian food, I recommend trying it once. It's unlike any other category of food. I wasn't sure what to expect when I first went to Jolly Bar. I had never had Ethiopian food before. So, I wasn't exactly sure how to eat the food when they brought it out--the meat with the flat, spongy bread (injera). Well, it turns out you just scoop up the meat dish with the injera. The food was decent and it is worth trying. If you're thinking about trying something new and being adventurous, I recommend this place. It will open your taste buds up to new flavors and new styles of food!

I was looking forward to trying this restaurant, as I enjoy the spices and veggie dishes from this part of the world. Had this been my first exposure, however, I would never eat anything Ethiopan again. The food, at best, was marginal. From the small size of the servings, I suspect they knew it wasn't worth the bother to eat. I'm not sure where or when these other pictures were taken by other commenters, but our platter, for three people, was better suited for two light eaters. After spending $75 for the meal (with one water, one iced tea, and a soda), we were all ready to eat again an hour later. For two vegetarians and one omnivore, there were three scoops of vegetables and another three scoops of some sort of meat. The portions looked like they used a single serving-spoon for each item. I don't mind Third World portions if they are Third World priced, but those two aspects were grossly disproportionate.

The d√©cor was rather tired and looked like it never really had a prime to be past. Perhaps that was intended to help convey the feel of economy where the food originated - not sure.

The wait staff was pleasant, but it would've been a plus if she had a better command of the English language, at least to the extent that she was clear on the difference between 'meat' and 'vegetable'.

Anyway, if you're one of the people that wrote or was influenced by the more positive reviews, rest assured you will never have to wait behind me for a table.

My rating is based off of the food that me and my gf ate. This is our 4th time at an Ethiopian place and this place had the best tasting platters. We ordered the veggie and the meat sampling plates with a lot of injera bread. We also ordered an extra order of beef tibs? I can't remember the exact name but the waitress said it was their special and it was DELICIOUS! Food was very good quality and it looks like this was a soft opening. 

Yes it was a bit expensive but we used the groupon and paid $36 before tip but we got A LOT of food. Eating at other Ethiopian places, they all seemed to cost around the same prices and they were all expensive so it wasn't like this place was especially costly.

It is located in an area that was a bit questionable. Not the best looking shopping center but don't let that deter you from eating here
Delicious food.  We 5 people enjoyed very much.  Great lamb and chicken .  We 've been to three Ethiopian restaurants and this one promises a return.  Owner is very nice.

This ultimately is not my type of food. My wife and I went here and I was not impressed. This is true Ethiopian food and if you've ever wanted to try real Ethiopian food, this is your place...it wasn't BAD, it just wasn't good.

An adventurous meal no doubt. We all 3 liked most of it.  I must admit we had no clue what most of it was though.  Yet we had no issues.  Some dishes were spicy. Some were bland. 

Our servers did a great job explaining what we had on our platter.  I bought a Groupon and it was worth it. Yet I can't say I would make this a regular spot. 

A true Ethiopian restaurant no doubt.

Meal was well prepared . Loved the lamb( you know when you cook lamb, there's a smell that can't be masked; this one has no smell) got them A+ for them. 
The meat + veggies combination was excellent. Loved the spicy they used. I'm a spicy food lover so I was in my zone...

A great deal from groupon. 

We came here for lunch one day to use the groupon deal and it was well worth the price we paid for the voucher. They offer very large portions and the food is very unique and delicious. We ordered 2 of the lunch combo specials under our waitress' recommendation. The menu is extensive and since I'm not too familiar with Ethiopian food, it was nice for her to explain what some of the items are and recommend the combo which contained a little bit of everything. 

We didn't wait too long before our drinks and food came out, it was a huge plate of pure goodness, lots of different things to try and the flavors were so unique and explosive. We shared some of the meat dishes like the lamb and beef. 

The service was a bit lacking and the restaurant smell like smoke, so minus 1 star. The bathrooms are reasonably clean.
The best food ever I think you should try this because it has the best lamb tibs ever I would recommend this place

We went here because there was a Groupon. Food was amazing and diffrent. Reason o give it 4 stars is because of the price. My combo plattter costs $18.95 and its just lentails and beans with a spoonful of meat. Diffently not $19 worth of food. Its good, i just would not go back without the groupon.

all the negative review was written by first time exotic eaters, the food  supposed to be spicy, dried and fatty meat. the funny one was ( spongy bread) its all the part of the experience. i understand the language issue being an issue. that's the only thing i see that need to get fixed. I like the Kitfo.

If there was a zero I'd use it.  We purchased a Groupon that didn't expire until August 8, 2016, mind you its still available for purchase for 2 more days as well. When we walked in, the first question was "do you have the Groupon" we said, "yes" and she informed us that we can not use it for another 2 or 3 months. We pulled up the Groupon to look for restrictions and there are NONE. She then told us "new management"...I assume that translates to, "we have your money and are going out of business but thanks"!  Horrible people. Too bad, too as we were looking forward to trying something new.

Found a Groupon for this place and decided to get it so we can check it out. The only Ethiopian place we knew of was Merkato. 

Environment: Low light, small and cozy. I like that they have booths on the side so it's almost private in a way. People aren't staring at you. 

Service: Not too bad. Had more service compared to Merkato in that the 2 waitresses stopped by a few times to see if we liked our food. Our main waitress was a younger lady who didn't speak English all to well so I would usually look at the other lady since she spoke more fluently. They were super nice but the young waitress was a bit slow and forgot to get us water when we asked. 

Food: I will have to say it is not bad at all. We ordered Sambusa, Zil Zil Tibs, meat combo and ayib cheese. They ran out of Sambusa so I asked if there were other appetizers that were good but I don't think she understood. She ended up brining out these mini Sambusa, so it looked as if the chef made some mini ones real quick. It was good. Their injera to me isn't all that great. Compared to Merkato's, it doesn't have a hint of sourdough flavor, it's a bit soft and breaks easily. It's more bland which is good too but I like Merkato's better. 

Price: compared to Merkato it is very expensive. For the meat combo it was $18, for Zil Zil Tibs it's $19, for their "electric tea" which is basically a hot Lipton bag tea it was $2.50, a water bottle was $1.50, maybe half cup of ayib cheese was $5, extra injera cost $5 so the whole bill ended up being $54. They didn't charge for the Sambusa so that saved us a few bucks. 

Hours: There is no place that states their hours, not even their website. When we got there, we saw it and it looks like they are open 7 days/week from 11am-2am.

This place is a dump! We ordered the lamb and the beef and both were chewy and overcooked. It is so hard to understand the accent of the waitress. We wanted explanation of the menu because it is our first time here. The price is not worth the quality and quantity of the food. We had to ask for silverware and napkins after the food was served. The waitress poked our bread with her fingers in front of us! Place was not clean, pictures on the wall were not even straightened. I would not come back here again.

We went in to use our groupon around 1pm. After waiting in front for 5+ mins without seeing anyone we had to go to the back and call out to get anyone to come up to the front. After the waitress came up we told her we wanted seating for 4. She then asked if we had a groupon and we said we did. She then told us that the new management does not accept groupons and that no exception would be made. We had been here 2 times before and while the food was good the service has never been great but this day it was just horrid. Groupon is an agreement and for a restaurant to renege on it is a  terrible sign. It seemed to me and those with me that they did not even want customers.

Was visiting Vegas and wanted to try some thing off the strip. What a find! 
Sweet place with fun Ethiopian music. 
We ordered the Jolly Messob 
It was huge and tasty. So many different flavors. The tortilla like bread was interesting, but I ended up loving them. The lamb was yummy. 
If you're looking for something different this place is a most to checkout.

Went back for lunch for the 3rd time today and they were unexpectedly closed!  Called the number listed on Groupon and their website and they hung up on us!! Something fishy here. Contacting Groupon hoping for a refund.

I love trying exotic cuisine (and have tried it all) so I was eager to check Ethiopian off the bucket list. 

Sadly, this was the biggest ripoff in my 5 years living in Vegas. 

I got a beef and onion/jalapeno dish for about $18 that had about as much meat as you'd expect to find in a carne asada taco.

The remaining 2 dishes ($16 a piece) were a spicy and mild curry type and were supposedly lamb dishes, but there was no lamb meat whatsoever, just bone parts and fragments and fat that I  had to keep spitting out onto a napkin. You'd find more lamb meat in one spoonful of any lamb dish in any Indian restaurant in town than I did in the entire disgusting bowl of "curry" which just tasted like sauce out of a can.

They top off your dining experience by giving you a cold flavorless nasty flat spongy bread to dip in the dishes that wasn't made fresh and came out of the fridge...imagine a soggy tasteless flat sponge that is about 50 degrees that you have to dip into a much warmer sauce and eat...giving someone a pre-made cold one to make the hot food cold lacks any culinary common sense....do Indian restaurants give you naan that's been sitting in a fridge to dip in your curry. No...and the fact that it is moist and spongy means the thing wouldn't even adjust to room temperature...it just remained a cold mess.

Another joke of the evening was the absence of a drink menu. So we just asked for iced water...not here...$2 bottled watered for a $4 total to wash down this nasty meal.

They could see by our unused soggy cold sponge and all the fat and bones I had to pick out of the sauce that we weren't too thrilled with our meal...that is when the added fun started. The 2 of us were tacked on 18% gratuity!!! Isn't that against the law? The worst meal of my life came to $65 with tax and I was going to leave $5 because we left hungry and were really upset at what we were given for such a high price...and we weren't even allowed to decide our own tip...THEY decided how much we should have enjoyed their meal and service.

They are a new business and I didn't want to slam a new business so early on yelp but the fact that we ate Wendy's an hour later due to still being hungry and that 18% added gratuity for a table of 2 still left me with a bitter taste (aside from the food) a couple days later..

Nothing Jolly here.

If I couldn't give negative stars I would.  My family and I were so excited to try a different ethnic food and came in.  There were two ladies sitting down, talking when we walked in.  No greeting whatsoever and then I asked if we seat ourselves.  They responded "yeah" and continues talking in their language.  My son which is 2 sat there patiently.  We sat for 2o minutes without one greeting or any menus to occupy time.  I myself am in customer service as a bartender of years experience and have traveled around the world.  This by far IS THE WORST EXPERIENCE I have experienced in my life.

We went to this place last night... the place that we went to looked NOTHING like their website, they had nothing on the menu compare to the site.. They charge $16.95 for awaze tibs compare to Merkato its 9.00... the meat was fatty. Do yourself a favor and do not go to this place. It was dirty as well.

This place has decent food but nothing amazing.  I don't think that it's overpriced, but I think that the service and food has room for improvement.  I enjoyed the lamb dish and the teff bread.  The salad was a little skimpy.  Our waitress spoke bad English.  However, it was only the second time that I had Ethiopian food.  I had a spicy beef dish with a homemade cottage cheese and I really couldn't recommend it.  Nice vegetarian selections which I would get next time.

I consider myself a foodie and love ethnic food however, the meal was unbalanced. The Lamb dish was tough and fatty, the beef dish was over the top too spicy. The salad was the best part and you get about 2 tablespoons worth. I thought the teff bread was interesting and I appreciate that it is gluten free. Something was missing all around. It looks like there is music on the weekends and a bar with the minimum selection of spirits. Hopefully they will fill in in the missing pieces. The waitress does not speak English well and hard to communicate. We had a Groupon and I was excited about trying Ethiopian food however, I won't be back.

Bland bread (with a refrigerator taste) and the service is horrible. Being that I lived in the Denver Aurora area for 15 months I know good African food.  Not coming back for another $15 vegetarian plate again.

And WHY did the server have a loud sigh of irritation when I asked her for cayenne pepper? It's not like she could've been overwhelmed with my request. 

I was the only customer in the establishment (?)
